Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: They are sorting files that contain detailed medical histories that must not be disclosed.
Story: I was sorting through stacks of confidential medical files at the community center, carefully checking each name and date, when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, someone I knew from my running group. “Hey, you know the area well—can you recommend a good restaurant for my friend? She has some dietary restrictions, so something accommodating would be great.” I glanced at the files in front of me. I’d just read about a new place that catered to specific allergies, but I only knew about it because I’d seen it listed in a client’s medical history. As an acquaintance, I wanted to help Mark and be friendly, but as a volunteer, I was bound to keep everything I learned here private. My mind raced, torn between wanting to be helpful and the heavy responsibility of confidentiality. I could feel the tension building inside me, my fingers hovering over the keyboard, unsure of what to say next.
